Articles.Content:
Hi all

1.1 finally here, so i tried to play and failed

I will write as much as i can about my issues, maybe someone will find it helpful

and maybe someone wil point me in the right direction

 

 

Im running Ubuntu 14.04 64bit  and radeon hd 7970 on a dual monitor setup

 


 

So after steam finished downloading the updated KSP i just clicked launch aaand... nothing

first of all, i noticed the steam tried to launch KSP 64bit version, instead of 'always 32' before, that's nice

 

anyway, when i tried to execute KSP.x86, it just thrown out some missing lib message. So i tried installing

all the missing 32bit libraries (like libXrender.so as far as i remember), and then it just started crashing just as the 64bit

so i focused on the 64bit version.  Just launching 

./KSP.x86_64

gives the output 

Set current directory to /home/scg/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Kerbal Space Program
Found path: /home/scg/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Kerbal Space Program/KSP.x86
Mono path[0] = '/home/scg/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Kerbal Space Program/KSP_Data/Managed'
Mono path[1] = '/home/scg/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Kerbal Space Program/KSP_Data/Mono'
Mono config path = '/home/scg/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Kerbal Space Program/KSP_Data/Mono/etc'
displaymanager : xrandr version warning. 1.4
client has 6 screens
displaymanager screen (0)(DFP5): 1920 x 1080
displaymanager screen (1)(CRT1): 1920 x 1080
Using libudev for joystick management


Importing game controller configs
Aborted (core dumped)

 

and game crashes.. . and the KSP.log isnt very helpful 

Kerbal Space Program - 1.1.0.1230 (LinuxPlayer)


OS: Linux 3.19 Ubuntu 14.04 64bit
CPU: AMD Phenom(tm) II X4 965 Processor (4)
RAM: 7975
GPU: AMD Radeon R9 200 / HD 7900 Series (2708MB)
SM: 30 (OpenGL 4.5 [4.5.13416 Compatibility Profile Context 15.20.1013])
RT Formats: ARGB32, Depth, ARGBHalf, Shadowmap, RGB565, ARGB4444, ARGB1555, Default, ARGB2101010, DefaultHDR, ARGBFloat, RGFloat, RGHalf, RFloat, RHalf, R8


Log started: Wed, Apr 20, 2016 13:24:26

 

 

this is all there is. So first i tried updating the graphic drivers from ATI to the lastest version,

and even tried to upgrade the kernel version to the lastest stable build (3.19.0-58). No change.

Eventually i figured out this was a problem with Unity, so i tried running KSP with some unity player parameters

 

  

./KSP.x86 -screen-fullscreen 0 -screen-width 1280 -screen-height 720

and it worked! Game started succesfully and i could play. It turns out the unity player might have some issues with multimonitor setup, thats why this helped.

Anyway, the game worked and i started playing, but soon started to notice some graphics glitches, like when i launched a rocket,

suddenly the rendering of Kerbin surface was messed up... And when i got to the Mun, and switch to surface view.... the mun was gone!!

I mean, it was still there just invisible...

Eventually the game crashed, cant even remember what i did to cause this. But i tried to launch it again the same way, but this time

it just crashed every time. Unity command line params wont help anymore, dont know why. I tried removing the whole game

and reinstalling fresh from steam, but still no effect.

 

And here's the Player.log from ~/.config/unity3d/Squad/Kerbal Space Program/

After an update to 1.1 on release day, I was able to play with ~30 mods included for one session (Some mods worked, some didn't, but KSP handled it as expected). Everything worked perfectly until I tried starting it up the next day - on startup, it would flicker between a 1280x720 window and a 2x720 window, both black. The KSP cursor becomes visible for a split second before this occurs, and the flicker doesn't begin until after the cursor appears.

Of course, the first step was to verify cache in Steam. That didn't fix it so i tried a completely fresh reinstall. When that didn't work, I tried to wipe everything that had anything to do with Kerbal (.config/unity3d and the KSP folder). This didn't work either, so I started researching how to solve the problem. 1 hour ago, keyspace said:

I've filed a bug report for the visual glitches: http://bugs.kerbalspaceprogram.com/issues/9647

 

That wasn't necessary, Squad is very much aware of this issue as it has been reported before, and existed during Experimentals and previous.

The Unity5 shaders do not work for all graphics cards and drivers, in particular for Linux AMD drivers but also for Linux Intel, and OSX drivers.

There is also a bug in the 5.2 version of the Unity engine that causes the OpenGL version to be misidentified, and the prefs file to be incorrect.

Unfortunately there's nothing Squad can do about this at this time, it is expected that Unity5.4 will fix these issues but it is still in beta, it is likely that KSP 1.2 will use Untiy5.4 though, simply because of the expected fixes.

Until then we have to make do with workarounds, and Unity5 games can be forced to re-detect the available OpenGL by using the -force-glcore command line argument.

-force-glcoreXX can be used to force a specific version of OpenGL, where XX is the GL version.

Also, -adapter N will force Unity games to use a specific monitor, where N is the monitor you want to use.

Also discussed here if it's of interest, in regards to the prefs file:

I use -force-glcore as an option at startup as well. As an aside to this if you are using KDE5, the Neon dev/stable repos ship Qt5.6.x which fix a host of multiscreen issues, at least for me. Try it out, it's an easy upgrade if already using Kubuntu 16.04

Edited May 13, 2016 by seevee

It's all here, or at least most of it, some older commands like -force-gfx-st and -force-opengl still work but are really for Unity4.

-force-glcore forces Unity to re-detect the available OpenGL versions and use the best one it finds.

-force-glcore33 forces OpenGL version 3.3

-force-gfx-direct forces Unity to use single threaded graphics rendering.

All these commands change how Unity works before any Squad code is loaded, and they should work for any graphics card though the results may vary.
